transcripts.text: So why does the left continue to resort to dehumanizing those they disagree with?  Here to debate, former Tucson police officer Brandon Tatum and Democratic strategist Antoine Seawright.  Thank you gentlemen both for being here.  Antoine, I'm going to start with you.  Brandon, you came with the proper attire.  Antoine, I'll start with you.  Why can't Trump supporters be human?

Well, they can't.  I would have not used the same words, perhaps, as the MSNBC guest.  And no disrespect to him or no hits on him.  At the end of the day, I think what's consistent is the fact that no one will disagree with the fact that Trump supporters are very loyal.  I think they all drink the Kool-Aid and they're drunk off the Kool-Aid and they perhaps will pass the Kool-Aid to other people.
Listen, you just made a nice concession and then you accused him of being a Kool-Aid drinker.

Because, Pete, even Trump will tell you himself, look, his supporters are very loyal.  I think he said it during the course of the campaign.  If he went down the street or whatever he said during the course of the campaign, they will always be with him.  And no one would disagree with that.  He has a base and a following that are very loyal to him and the things that he believes.
So, Brandon, is Antoine being a bit too generous in saying this guest is basically just saying you're very loyal?

I'm glad Antoine didn't jump all the way off the boat.  But this is what I'll say.  We're not loyal to President Trump.  We're loyal to America.  And President Trump is defending America.  And as long as he's defending America and doing what's right, we'll stand by those principles.  It's simple and plain.

Antoine, I think that's a very fair point.  I mean, Trump supporters would say if he was doing the wrong things, ultimately we wouldn't be with him.  But he's fighting in a way no one else has.  I mean, can you acknowledge that?

Pete, Pete.  Pete and Brandon, if you look at some of the rhetoric that comes from this president, if you look at some of the behavior and you think that's doing what's best for America, then yes, you are drunk on the Kool-Aid.  And listen, Brandon, I believe in what's best for America.  I'm very loyal to this country.  But that doesn't mean I agree with everything the president does and the president says.  And if you don't call him out for the things he does wrong or the things he say that are wrong, then you and I both have a problem.

Well, it's not a matter of calling him out for what's wrong or right.  The bottom line is this.  We're talking about the emergency that he's ordered.  We're talking about border security.  We're talking about the things that he's been able to accomplish for this country.  And I support all of those things.  Give me an example of something that he's done that's anti-American.
I want to get...
Well, some of the rhetoric he uses.

Okay, well, we can argue over the rhetoric.  But I want to get to a story we're hearing more about today.  Jesse Smollett, the actor who made accusations about an attack on him a number of weeks ago by MAGA supporters yelling racist and homophobic things.  Now, this morning, Brandon, we're hearing the Chicago police have shifted the investigation.  They no longer consider him a victim.  They're getting new evidence that may suspect, that may allege that this was not an attack at all.  It may be orchestrated by a couple people that he potentially knew.  Brandon, your reaction to this?

But look, racism in this country is literally on life support.  It's dying.  People like myself and a lot of people in the conservative movement are literally trying to pull the plug.  But the left seems to want to revive racism every chance we get.  This is a fake faux outrage that was recreated and paid for by a man.  If racism was so bad, then why do you have to pay to create it?  That man should be ashamed of himself.  He should be ashamed of himself for what he's doing to represent his family and represent people on his side of the aisle.  He should be ashamed.

We don't know what happened yet.  That's what I'm happy to say on the air today.  But so many people, including Democratic presidential candidates, jumped in right away and said this is a modern-day lynching.  Is not that type of rhetoric, without knowing the facts, creating a racial lens where maybe one didn't exist?

Pete, you and I have been at this before, so I will be very consistent because I appreciate you having me on.  I will be very consistent and say, let's let the facts play out and let's see how this plays out.  If what Brandon and others are speculating is true, then it's very unfortunate.  It's like the boy that cries wolf.  And what it does is it sets a very dangerous precedent and it puts a real... I think it puts an unwarranted pressure on these situations when they come up before.  And it's like people will never believe you when you actually have these scenarios and situations.  However, I strongly disagree with Brandon, the fact that racism is essentially non-existent.  America's carpet has lumps in it because we swept racism up under the rug for so very long in this country.  And we cannot allow this to be a distraction for calling things out from which they are very, very true.
Briefly, last word, Brandon.

Well, why do they have to recreate these scenarios?  Why can't the man just be walking down the street and actually get beat up by white people who are racist against him?  He had to pay other brothers to do it.
Listen, I was a former police officer.

I don't disagree with you.  I understand how the process works.  When they are investigating two individuals and they let them go without charging them, and now they're focusing their attention on Jussie Smollett, he is going to be charged.  I don't disagree with you.
All my point in this is let's let the police do their job.
Well, that's not what Democratic candidates were doing at the beginning.
I can only speak for the gospel according to Antoine.
Fair enough.  All right, Brendan, thank you both.  Brendan Tatum and Antoine Seawright for the good debate this morning.  Appreciate it.  Good stuff.
